## PhD Researcher
<span style="font-size:1.15rem; color:#4b5563;">
Granular Flow · DEM Simulations · Pattern Formation
</span>

I am a computational physicist specializing in dense granular flow and particle-based simulation. Using large-scale Discrete Element Method (DEM) models, I study how particle geometry and contact mechanics govern stress transmission, shear localization, dilatancy, and evolving surface profiles in sheared granular systems. Coarse-graining techniques are used to extract continuum fields — velocity, strain-rate, and the full stress tensor — relating particle-scale interactions to macroscopic behavior.

I also study pattern formation and emergent phenomena in complex systems, including reaction–diffusion models exhibiting Turing instabilities, both numerically and analytically. My research involves numerical modeling, scientific programming, and systematic data analysis in high-performance computing environments.

**Currently:** PhD Researcher (FAU Germany)

:::

## Featured Projects

::: {.columns}
::: {.column width="50%"}

### Alignment-induced depression and shear thinning in granular matter of nonspherical particles
DEM study of shear-induced alignment, surface depression formation, and shear-thinning rheology of elongated grains.  
➡️ [Read more →](./projects/shearthinning.qmd)

:::

::: {.column width="50%"}

### Impact of friction and grain shape on the morphology of sheared granular media
DEM study of how friction and particle shape control alignment, dilatancy, and free-surface morphology in a linear split-bottom shear cell.  
➡️ [Read more →](./projects/friction-shape-morphology.qmd)

:::
:::

::: {.columns}
::: {.column width="50%"}

### Pattern selection in a three-component Gray–Scott model (2019)
Analytical study of diffusion-driven instability and pattern formation in a reaction–diffusion system.  
➡️ [Read more →](./projects/grayscott.qmd)
